Chapter 2.41


Summer 1436, Late Afternoon


The private corridors of the Alcázar are blessedly cool after the stifling heat of the Great Hall. Your footsteps echo on stone worn smooth by generations of Castilian kings as you walk beside Lucia, her hand resting lightly on the swell of her belly. The guards have spread out—two ahead, two behind, and the children's protectors flanking their charges with practiced vigilance.


Catalina walks a few paces ahead, her small spine still straight with that unnatural poise that so captivated the assembled lords. She has not spoken since leaving the hall, but you catch glimpses of her face in the torchlight—not triumphant, not exhausted, but calculating, as if reviewing her performance for flaws to correct. Behind her, Fernando clings to his nurse's hand, his fine clothes already rumpled, his earlier shyness having given way to a quiet exhaustion. Bianca toddles between them, oblivious to the day's significance, while Teresa sleeps in her nurse's arms.


The Count of Alba's words echo in your mind: A danger beyond reckoning.


"The Duke of Medina Sidonia asked twice when Catalina might visit his estates," Lucia murmurs, low enough for only you to hear. "And Count Benavente's invitation was genuine—I saw his face. She has made admirers of men who would normally dismiss a child." She pauses. "She also has the Archbishop's attention now. And Torquemada was watching her very closely during the blessing."


You reach the door to the family apartments. A servant opens it, and warm light spills out—lamps already lit, a small fire in the hearth despite the season (Lucia feels cold easily now). The children's evening meal waits on a low table. Normalcy, after a day that was anything but.

A servant is dispatched. You settle the children with their nurses—Catalina already recovered from her performance and asking pointed questions about the Duke of Medina Sidonia's family history, Fernando clutching a small wooden knight and looking relieved to be away from the crowd.


Perhaps a quarter-hour passes before Diego de Daza arrives, ink-stained fingers and a leather satchel stuffed with documents marking his perpetual state of industrious preparation. He bows to Lucia, then to you.


"Your Majesty summoned me. I came directly from the counting house."


He takes a seat when you gesture, pulling a wax tablet from his satchel—his portable notes, always at hand.


At your question about one-time expenses for 1436, Diego consults his tablet and frowns thoughtfully.


"The Salé expedition... yes, Your Majesty, that was authorized." He flips through notes. "A punitive raid against the corsairs who have been troubling the Strait. The fleet conducted operations in the spring—I would need to pull the final accounting, but I believe we allocated approximately eight to ten thousand florins for the operation itself. Supplies, crew bonuses, ammunition expended."


He pauses, thinking. "Beyond that... the major one-time expense this year was the foundry expansion—six thousand florins for the second furnace and workforce recruitment, as approved during your review with Signore Calabrese."


Diego taps his stylus against the tablet. "And there is the continuing African commitment—the forty thousand florins to Prince Henry for the Senegal outpost and Timbuktu expedition was committed this year, though it disburses over three years. I would need to confirm how much has actually been sent versus pledged."


He looks up. "For the definitive budget, Your Majesty, I require clarity on a few matters. First, should the African disbursements be counted as one-time expenses in the year pledged, or split across the years of actual payment? Second, the naval operating costs have increased significantly—Admiral Vilaragut reports the combined fleet now requires closer to forty-five thousand florins annually rather than the thirty-seven thousand projected. Do you wish me to revise projections accordingly?"


He hesitates. "And there is the matter of the Barcelona journey next spring. A royal progress with the full family, guards, and appropriate state... that will not be inexpensive. Shall I include an estimate for that as well?"

"Very good, Your Majesty. Counting the full African commitment in this year simplifies the accounting considerably. And the Barcelona meeting—I shall note that any expenses will be handled through the royal household's existing allocations." He pauses. "If circumstances change, we can revisit."

He looks up from the parchment. "The net position is a surplus of sixty-two thousand, eight hundred fifty florins. This brings the year-end treasury to five hundred eighty-five thousand, six hundred fifty-one florins."


Diego permits himself a small smile—a rare expression from the usually dour administrator. "A recovery from the investment year of 1435, Your Majesty. If the projections hold, we should see the treasury exceed one million florins by 1439, and approach one and a half million by 1441."
